arguments.argument: The death penalty is irreversible and risks executing innocent people.
Capital punishment violates the fundamental human right to life.
Life imprisonment is a more humane and effective alternative.
The death penalty has not been proven to deter crime effectively.
Execution methods can be cruel and cause unnecessary suffering.
The death penalty disproportionately affects marginalized communities.
Legal systems are fallible, leading to wrongful convictions.
It is more expensive to execute someone than to imprison them for life.
Many countries have abolished it without an increase in crime rates.
Forgiveness and rehabilitation align better with modern justice values.
The death penalty provides justice and closure for victims' families.
It serves as a strong deterrent against heinous crimes.
Some crimes are so severe that execution is the only fitting punishment.
The death penalty ensures that dangerous criminals never reoffend.
It can reduce prison overcrowding and long-term incarceration costs.
Execution is a faster resolution compared to lifelong imprisonment.
The death penalty reflects the principle of retributive justice.
Some religious and cultural traditions support capital punishment.
Modern execution methods aim to minimize suffering.
Keeping criminals alive can sometimes inspire copycat crimes or radicalization.
